Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5R67-3GJ1-DXH2-64BV-00000-00GOP Finalizes Tax Bill; Senate GOP Can Lose No More Than Two Votes in Order to Pas Tax Bill; Mueller's Probe Bias Concerns; Net Neutrality Hysteria; Rubio a "Yes" on Tax Reform; Bitcoin Billionaires; Haley: Iran in Violation; Retail Sales Jump in Now; Tax Brackets Released; "Star Wars" Frenzy2017-12-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:56:44ZLexisNexisINTELLIGENCE REPORT2:00 PM ESTDavid Bruno, Ned Ryun, Paul DergarabedianNEWSInternational121501cb.232GOP Finalizes Tax Bill; Senate GOP Can Lose No More Than Two Votes in Order to Pas Tax Bill; Mueller's Probe Bias Concerns; Net Neutrality Hysteria; Rubio a "Yes" on Tax Reform; Bitcoin Billionaires; Haley: Iran in Violation; Retail Sales Jump in Now; Tax Brackets Released; "Star Wars" FrenzyAshley Webster, Adam Shapiro, Jason Chaffetz, Blake Burman, Nicole Petallides, Deirdre Bolton, Walid Phares, Jeff Flock

NEIL CAVUTO, FOX BUSINESS HOST: So much we don't know but Ashley Webster knows everything about it. He will be in now for Trish. Ashley.

ASHLEY WEBSTER, FOX NEWSHOST: That's what I tell everybody. I don't know if anyone believes it.

CAVUTO: I believe it.

WEBSTER: Thank you very much, Neil.

Well, we will see that finalized version of the Republican tax bill in just a few hours from now. Lawmakers making last minute changes, specifically the child tax credit, following Senator Marco Rubio's threat to vote no on that bill if the credit is not expanded. But it is still a little bit unclear if this is enough to secure a yes vote from Rubio. We'll talk about that.

But the uncertainty over tax reform having little impact on the market today, as you can see another nice rally, the Dow up a 156 points, 24,664. Remarkable. Good afternoon, everybody. I'm Ashley Webster. In today for Trish Regan to the -- and we begin now with "The Intelligence Report.

Let's get right to it. Republicans can only afford, we know this, to lose two GOP senators if they want to get this tax bill passed.

And well, there are a handful that, well, we could see are on the fence right now, including Senators Mike Lee, Bob Corker, what about Jeff Flake? So the question is, can they get it done? We'll be asking former Utah Congressman Jason Chaffetz. He is here in the studio with us.

Plus, President Trump, blasting the FBI handling of the Hillary Clinton email scandal. The President even calling that probe rig and that he's ever seen anything like this before. I have more on that in just a few minutes.

But first, let's go to our very own Adam Shapiro for the latest on this tax reform fight. The clock is ticking. Adam, is this thing going to get through?

ADAM SHAPIRO, FOX BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT: When you speak to talk to people at the administration and on Capitol Hill that's a very simple yes. They expect it to pass.

Now, where we stand right now, we do expect Marco Rubio to vote yes on this bill because he has gotten a decisional $300 for the child tax credit refund that he wanted. This would come against through payroll taxes on the first -- what is it? Roughly zero to $25,000 in income. In simple terms, if you don't have federal income tax liability he wanted to increase the amount you would get back for a child tax credit.

So he is seems to have achieve that. And as a member of the Conference Committee, the source close to conference committee, he told me we'll give him what he wants and he'll be yes.

The other two though, the undecided are Senator Flake and Senator Corker. Even if they were to vote no, that still may not be enough to kill the bill and there is all kind of calculations that go into it. But everyone is expecting a yes next week.

Now, what we know at this point, according to Representative Jordan as well a Kevin Brady, the Conference Committee is done. They have signed the report. It is closed, and we will find out when it is filed publicly at 5:30, the exact details in there that they will vote upon next week. But here is what Kevin Brady said just moments ago.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

KEVIN BRADY (R-TX), CHAIRMAN OF THE HOUSE WAYS AND MEANS COMMITTEE: I'm confident at end of the day, the Senate will approve this Conference Committee report because, no one should be defending the status quo in this horrible tax code. Americans have had to live for with for too long.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SHAPIRO: But the key question everybody has, as exactly what kind of changes were made? For instance, we know the top income tax bracket was lowered to 37 percent but what about other tax brackets, remember, the Senate version had seven brackets whereas the House had four brackets.

Well, President Trump says, he has been kept the prize of everything that's going on with the bill. And here is what he said before he went to speak at FBI graduation ceremony this morning.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP (R), PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: I have seen it. I think it's going to do very, very well. I think that we are going to be in a position to pass something as early as next week which will be monumental.

(OFF-MIC)

TRUMP: I think they will be great. They're great people. They want to see it done. We're putting in a tremendous child tax credit. And it is increasing on a daily basis.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SHAPIRO: So the bottom line answer to your question is everybody at least on the administration and on Capitol Hill with an R next to their name, an R for Republican is expecting this to pass.

WEBSTER: We shall see, yes. Adam, thank you very much for the latest.

Joining me now here at the studio, Fox NewsContributor and former Utah Congressman Jason Chaffetz.

Jason, thank you so much for being here. We just got a note from Chad Pergram, the Senior Producer for Fox News, he says Jeff Flake, Bob Corker, Mike Lee, all three still undecided on this bill. What do you think, how does this play out?

JASON CHAFFETZ, FOX NEWSCONTRIBUTOR: Oh I think ultimately Marco Rubio, Jeff Flake and Mike Lee will be a yes. I don't think they will going to be the last person standing putting up a blockade on this. I think --

WEBSTER: Would you want to be as a no --

CHAFFETZ: I don't think they will. I think the child tax credit is actually the way it is structured is bad public policy but nevertheless they did coalesce and get behind that, and support it, and expand it. But the ones who watch are Corker, Collins and McCain.

WEBSTER: Yes.

CHAFFETZ: Only lose two as we talked about --

WEBSTER: Right.

CHAFFETZ: Ultimately I do think it happens. And I think by the time you get to the end of the day Tuesday, perhaps Wednesday, it will have passed. But hours later the funding of government will be the issue --

WEBSTER: The appropriations.

CHAFFETZ: The euphoric high that will being tax reform passing will be demolished within hours when they get to the reality of how to fund the government.

WEBSTER: I want to get that in a minute. But I want to get back to Marco Rubio. Some of this red line from him came out of nowhere. Were you surprised? I think or Republican leadership was a little surprised?

CHAFFETZ: Well, we always knew that Mike Lee and Marco Rubio were very intent on doing it. They did put it up for a vote and it failed. But they held the line. And it's the way you get attention is hold out a no vote. You keep saying no, no. And suddenly the White House and everybody from leadership and the --

WEBSTER: Yes.

CHAFFETZ: --- Ways and Means and Senate Finance come over and say what can we do? And he managed to get another $300 in there. And for those families it will make a difference, but again I think the public policy side of it is wrong.

WEBSTER: So this gets through. Bob Corker's opposition has been the expense. What are we doing about spending as the deficit gets larger and larger? As conservative, are you worried about that?

CHAFFETZ: Well, I wish he was more concern about the deficit on the spending side. I don't think you have to justify allowing the American people to hold their own money in their own pockets.

WEBSTER: Right.

CHAFFETZ: But what you do have to do is make tough choices, and stop spending so much money.

WEBSTER: Yes.

CHAFFETZ: And this Republican Congress, House and Senate have been terrible in actually cutting spending. Name anything that they have cut? And the answer is zero. There is nothing.

WEBSTER: You're right.

CHAFFETZ: There is nothing and I think that it is wrong to say, well, you know, if times get tough that we raise taxes. That's exactly the wrong time to raise taxes.

WEBSTER: Yes.

CHAFFETZ: But you have to curve back spending up which they have done nothing.

WEBSTER: So listen, this is going to be the first major legislative success for the GOP if they can get this done.

CHAFFETZ: Yes.

WEBSTER: We believe they will. You never know. It ain't over until it's over.

CHAFFETZ: Right.

WEBSTER: Going into next year, I think attention will probably turns to infrastructure. Any issues with that? Should that get through? That shouldn't be a big political football, should it?

CHAFFETZ: Well, you've increased defense spending now to $664 billion. And I do think the continuing resolution will fund that through the end of September of 2018.

WEBSTER: Yes.

CHAFFETZ: You have the infrastructure spending that you have to do as a supplemental, they call it, it's like the term in Congress for the disaster relief because of Irma and other hurricanes.

WEBSTER: Yeah.

CHAFFETZ: That's going to approach $100 billion over time. I don't know where you go back and say, now we're going to infuse, you know, tens, if not 100 plus billion dollars in infrastructure.

WEBSTER: Right.

CHAFFETZ: It all sounds great until you actually look at the red line and you see --

WEBSTER: You have to pay for it.

CHAFFETZ: How you pay for it.

WEBSTER: Is that where you bring in the private sector.

CHAFFETZ: Well, you do want to have public/private partnerships.

WEBSTER: But the government has to kick in to pay a lot?

CHAFFETZ: Yes. And states also have to be involved. But you have to figure out where to go, to make those hard choices and say, instead of spending money here, let's spend it over here.

WEBSTER: Right.

CHAFFETZ: That's going to be a contentious discussion. Although I do think Democrats want to come to the table on that, because it is something they do want.

WEBSTER: Do you miss it?

CHAFFETZ: I miss part of the fight. I miss the people. You know, I have good friend there that -- you know from Tim Scott to Trey Gowdy and John Radcliffe, and Mia Love and other, I miss interacting with but --

WEBSTER: What don't you miss?

CHAFFETZ: Fund-raising. I hate fund-raising.

WEBSTER: You're always in that move?

CHAFFETZ: I'd always -- and got a better balance to my life and --

WEBSTER: Right.

CHAFFETZ: -- and nice little perch here with my relationship with Fox so.

WEBSTER: That's nice. But, you know, listen, a lot of people from it across this country look and say, why is it so dysfunctional? Is it dysfunctional? Certainly appears to be a lot of the time.

CHAFFETZ: I think in part it was structured that way by our founders.

WEBSTER: OK.

CHAFFETZ: It's not supposed to be a glide path to making this pass an easy.

WEBSTER: Sure.

CHAFFETZ: You got 535 people with big egos all wanting to make decisions and have their hands in the pot. It's an ugly sausage-making process.

WEBSTER: But it seems the environment is so much more contentious as it has been. I know it has been over the years, since day one, but it does seem very much either you're with us or you're not. There is not a lot of compromise.

CHAFFETZ: I wish people would stick to their principle whether their party was in power or not in power. Because I see both sides of the aisle suddenly they flip on a principle --

WEBSTER: Yes.

CHAFFETZ: Because now they're in the minority. You know, and that just drives you nuts.

WEBSTER: You got your life back financially. That's the most important thing. Jason, thank you very much. I appreciate it.

CHAFFETZ: Thank you.

WEBSTER: Turning to our other top story now, President Trump blasting the FBI's handling of the Hillary Clinton email scandal. The President even calling that probe rigged. He used that word. And that he has never seen anything like it before.

Well, for the very latest bring let's in our own Blake Burman, he's been following this from the White House. Blake?

BLAKE BURMAN, FOX BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT: Hi, there, Ashley. And I asked the President earlier today as he was leaving the White House whether or not he thought the special counsel is biased, which is what many Republicans here in Washington up on Capitol Hill have alleged.

The President was not willing earlier today to engage in that possibility when I asked him about it. However, he did use it as a launching pad to sharply criticize the FBI's handling of the Hillary Clinton email investigation.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: Whatever you want to call it, you going to make up your own determination, but they have found tremendous things on the other side. When you look at the Hillary Clinton investigation that was -- you know, I've been saying it for a long time. That was a rigged system, folks. That was a rigged system.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: Now those comments came a day after Senator Ron Johnson claimed in a letter to FBI Director Chris Wray, that James Comey's July statement which eventually cleared Clinton from any criminal wrongdoing had been watered down with three edits. One edit said, it was "possible that hostile actors" gained access to Clinton's private server, a downgrade from "reasonably likely."

Now Ashley, it is unclear exactly who made those edits, why they made those edits and when they made those edits. Senator Johnson in that letter said, he did not know exactly when the edits were made, those exact dates. So on one hand it could have just been potentially the normal investigative work as more information comes in, you make changes to your findings. Or it could have been as some have suggested that the FBI was in it, some at least to help out Hillary Clinton. Ashley?

WEBSTER: Yes, indeed. All right, Blake Burman, thank you very much for the latest on this.

Joining me now, Criminal Defense Attorney and former prosecutor, David Bruno and American Majority CEO Ned Ryun.

Thank you both, gentlemen, for being here. David, let me begin with you.

DAVID BRUNO, CRIMINAL DEFENSE ATTORNEY: Sure.

WEBSTER: You say that the underlying conduct by Director Comey and his officials is troubling and may be criminal. Where does the line get crossed a bit for it to be criminal?

BRUNO: Well, right now, there is an inspector general investigation that is going on and we will be getting the report shortly. But the most troubling aspect of this is the edits that we just heard about in the memorandum.

WEBSTER: Right.

BRUNO: Because one of the edits took away the language in the federal statute that would have made a crime for Hillary Clinton to abuse the classified documents.

WEBSTER: Right.

BRUNO: And that's gross negligence. It was originally included and for whatever reason by whoever it was modified, it was redacted and it was changed to careless.

WEBSTER: Right, which got Hillary Clinton off the hook, essentially.

BRUNO: Sure. If you get away from gross negligence into carelessness, it's no longer a federal crime.

WEBSTER: All right, Ned, let me get to you, I was reading your talking points, you have some strong views on this. You were saying look, you talk about Mueller's team, a partisan pack of wolves. You say --

NED RYUN, AMERICAN MAJORITY CEO: That's right.

WEBSTER: -- the findings are chilling. Kind if expand on that a little bit. What was the moats troubling aspect of this?

RYUN: Well, first of all, I mean, I think it's becoming very clear over the last couple weeks that Mueller's team is partisan pack of wolves. When you look at Peter Strzok, when you look at Andrew Weissmann, when you look at Jeannie Rhee and now you look at Aaron Zebley, I mean, I'm very hard press to think that these people are objective and I think our biases to influence a lot of our decisions as human being.

So to say that it's person I think it's understatement but even more so, Ashley, I think what we're seeing it the unfolding -- unwrapping of what I think is one of the biggest political crimes we've seen in our history, in which our government and a political party colluded together to undermine and to destroy and nullify the election of the other party.

And so I think when we look at this, all of the American people, they should find this chilling. They should be deeply concerned about what's taking place inside of their government and I there's more to come, Ashley. I think we're going to see more revelations coming out in the coming weeks in which people will start to fully understand, this is not good.

And I will say this, if Mike Pompeo and Jeff Sessions and Christopher Wray are concerned about the constitution and the civil liberties of the American people, they will protect those and not the institution. They should be more concerned about our freedom than protecting institutions.

WEBSTER: You know, David, look, we all have our own opinions, our own political leanings, if you like, and OK, so these FBI investigators have their own political likes but the line seems to me -- there were certain excerpts from some of these texts or emails where they say look, they make reference to the point that we need some sort of insurance policy just to make sure this guy, i.e., Donald Trump doesn't get elected. To me that crosses the line.

BRUNO: Yes. OK.

WEBSTER: You know, we can't take the risk. You know, to Ned's point, there's almost, you know -- people talk about the deep state conspiracy, I mean, this really smells -- doesn't smell right, let me put it that way.

BRUNO: I agree with you. There is nothing wrong with a bias so long as it doesn't result in actions that are against the law.

WEBSTER: Right?

BRUNO: Right, so --

WEBSTER: Change the course of history maybe.

BRUNO: So generally speaking the fact that one has a political affiliation is not a problem, however, if it goes to the next step and like you said, in the August text messages with agent Strzok talks about an insurance policy. And it also talks about a discussion in Andrew's office.

WEBSTER: Yes, that's right.

BRUNO: That could be Andrew McCabe.

WEBSTER: Correct.

BRUNO: About the election which could be a hatch violation. Hatch violations are when the government talks about political affairs or gets involved in political actions. Possible hatch violation if that in fact took place.

WEBSTER: So Ned, I mean, you obviously believe we should have an investigation of the investigators. I mean, how should this be playing out? Should Mueller be coming out and addressing this right away?

RYUN: I think when this -- Well, I do. At this point though, I was talking with the former DOJ official, and he said I still actually respect Mueller but I will find any of his findings, not believable.

WEBSTER: Yes.

RYUN: And so I think you've got a credibility problem. But Ashley, even more importantly what do we even talking about with this investigation as a whole? I believe it was started on false pretenses, a fake dossier that spun all of this up. And so I would actually argue that the instigation as a whole, regardless of the partisan nature of the team is illegitimate in of itself. And so I think we need to start having that conversations about, is this investigation even a legitimate one moving forward?

WEBSTER: That's a good point. What do you say, David?

BRUNO: Well, I talked about the inspector general before. Right now the inspector general is reviewing the Hillary Clinton FBI investigation.

WEBSTER: Right.

BRUNO: And the inspector general's office is the watchdog over the DOJ. So if there is any impropriety going on in the Mueller investigation right now, there will be a review at some point by the inspector general.

WEBSTER: Ned, you know, what we want and what we're not getting is we want some sunlight on this. And we want transparency.

RYUN: That's right.

WEBSTER: How do we do that? What should be done from this point forward?

RYUN: We declassify. I think the only way that the people of America can start to trust the DOJ and the FBI again, is I think we need to have some extreme transparency. I think we need to go back and declassify a lot of what took place over the last eight years.

I know that people again, the heads of these departments right now might not be comfortable doing that, but Ashley, I that is only way we can get back to having trust and faith in these institutions is to really declassify. What happened with Clinton and Loretta Lynch on that tarmac in Arizona? What really did happened with Comey's clearing of Hillary Clinton? What happened with Peter Strzok? The only way we get to that we have to declassify.

WEBSTER: And of course, David, in the background of all of this is we have the Russia investigation. The collusion which the President addressed earlier today when you're saying, there is no collusion. What have you found so far? They haven't anything, right?

BRUNO: Right. I mean, well, we don't know, right? We have multiple indictments --

WEBSTER: We've been going on for a long time.

BRUNO: We have a couple indictments. We have to two police (ph), one by George Papadopoulos and Mike Flynn.

WEBSTER: But directly link to --

BRUNO: Right. And that is pending. It's going on. We don't know. We will see at this point, absolutely. We have not seen any collusion or conspiracy that goes right to the White House.

WEBSTER: Yes, Ned, how long does this go on for?

RYUN: Well, this -- but the point I want to make is, we've had this thing going on for at least a year-and-a-half, almost two yes. And I've made this argument to people. Use your common sense. You had heads of intelligence agencies that didn't like Trump. You have a deep state bureaucracy that doesn't like Trump. And yet, the opposition party, the mainstream media that doesn't like him. If there was actually something there, don't you think we would have heard of it right now?

And so I'd argue, again there is nothing evidence there is many evidence that never will be evidence, of the fairy tale of Trump-Russia collusion.

WEBSTER: All right, we have to leave it right there. David, Ned, thank you so much. Great conversation. I really appreciate it.

BRUNO: Thanks, Ashley.

WEBSTER: Take a look at the market today and by the way, nice rally going on, the Dow up 163 points. We're at 24,670 on the Dow. The S&P up one percent, the Nasdaq also going great guns, up at more than one percent, up 6938 on the Nasdaq.

All right, we'll have more on the markets and so much more after this.

WEBSTER: Now, check it out, stocks broadly higher today with the Dow up triple digits. We had session highs just a few seconds ago. In fact, there is a new Intraday record for the Dow. It seems like we say it every day. Investor reacting to some positive earnings and retail sales, and guess what? Our very own Nicole Petallides live at always at the New York Stock Exchange, with more on a buying spree this Friday, Nicole.

NICOLE PETALLIDES, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: That's right. It is heavy volume. It is quadruple-witching. And we have some rebalancing. I'm just telling you it's going to be a really heavy volume day.

In addition to that, right now we're up 160 points on the Dow Jones Industrial average, near our session highs. We're clocking in another winning week, right? So the Dow will be up four weeks in a row and at the close, it will be our 69th record, which will tied the all-time amount of closing records for any given year, which is back in 1995. If we have one more after this, Ash, we will go down in history as most records ever.

We're talking a looking, not only as the Dow, the Nasdaq and the S&P which have up arrows. But you can see, since Election Day, the Dow Jones Industrial average up about 35 percent, the S&P up about 25 percent. So we certainly have enjoyed a nice run. It was a lot obviously built in on tax reform and the overall, which certainly seems to going well today, on the latest amendments that have been made on the child tax reform to appeal Rubio and Lee -- Senators Rubio and Lee.

So that's -- while taking a look at Costco, and Adobe, both of which had positive quarterly earnings, look at Costco up 3.5 percent, Adobe 1.6 percent, new high there by the way for Costco taking a look at some of the other retailers, big picture cracks up 17 percent, getting an upgrade over at Stifel, Nicolaus and just talking about their exposure abroad and that does well.

Remember when the stock is 75 bucks about 10 years ago? Forget that, how about you focus on this, great day today, Under Armour some positive comments there from the analysts as well and also foot locker getting an upgrade and getting the margins, going forward we'll watch the margins. You can see that too was a winner.

Overall, we will say that Moody has talked about the run up, recent run-up that we've seen in retail. It might be exhaustive. So we'll see that the latest retail sales numbers, Ashley, were pretty great. I mean, they were showing straight to people, spending on things that they don't really need, furniture, electronics, sporting good, books, music. So the latest numbers were pretty good showing holiday shoppers were hitting the stores. Back to you.

WEBSTER: I always need electronics. I'm just saying, I'm a kind of gadget guy, Nicole. So it's always an excuse to buy electronics. I love it. Anyway, thank you so much. Great stuff. Who knows, Dow 25,000 by Christmas? Maybe.

Meanwhile, backlash today over the roll back of Obama-era net neutrality rules, with all the hysteria out there, you think, well the internet as we know it is coming to an end. Our own Deirdre Bolton is here to cut through all the noise. And she will be next.

WEBSTER: We are just getting word from our colleagues at Fox Newsthat Marco Rubio is indeed a yes now on the tax bill. He got what he wanted, a bump in that refund on the child tax credit. He is in on board, we are told, still, we don't know about Bob Corker, Mike Lee, Jeff Flake, Susan Collins, still some questions to be answered. But Marco Rubio essentially got what he wanted. Now he says yes to the tax bill.

Also the FCC voting to end net neutrality rules guarantying equal access to the internet. Now most experts say, these changes won't have much impact in the short term. Others are resorting to complete hysteria.

CNN actually reported this as, the "End of the internet." Sentiments shared by Senator Bernie Sanders who tweeted Congress and the courts need to fight back.

Meanwhile, others have said this is attack on LBGT community. Some on Twitter even said we will going to die.

I kid you not. Deirdre Bolton is here now. Deirdre --

DEIRDRE BOLTON, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Well, we're all going to die at some point but it is not in direct relation to repeal of --

WEBSTER: Yes. But should we be in a panic? Come on.

BOLTON: So, listen, it is not the end of the internet as we know with the soundtrack, right.

WEBSTER: Yes.

BOLTON: But it is the beginning of a huge fight.

WEBSTER: OK.

BOLTON: So you have 20 states attorney generals, they've lined up to sue the FCC calling the agency's move, a violation of the law and a serious threat to the free exchange of ideas.

So here is a map. We made a list of states that are beginning to take a legal action against the FCC. So I'm not going to read all the names. But you can see them, north, south, east, west more adding themselves as we speak.

So the tech community going bonkers. Facebook's Sheryl Sandberg, Microsoft's Brad Smith, execs from Google, Airbnb, a whole list, speaking out. This is Netflix's statement as further tweet this morning. "We're disappointed in the decision to gut net neutrality protections that ushered in an unprecedented era of innovation, creativity and civic engagement. This is the beginning of a longer legal battle. Netflix stands with innovators, large and small, to oppose this misguided FCC order."

Now Netflix, other big tech companies, they're taking a stand on the vote on principle because the service providers such as Verizon, Comcast, AT&T, they can charge Netflix more money because Netflix uses more internet capacity when we all binge watch our shows. But it doesn't matter, Netflix can pay.

So the reason big tech is fighting the FCC is because big tech says the vote kills innovation. So for example, if there is future competitor out there to Google, Amazon, Facebook, Netflix trying to build itself up now, a fledgling company, the arguments goes would not even be able to get off the ground and afford the fees that a Verizon, or a Comcast, or an AT&T would have the power to demand.

FCC Chairman Ajit Pai, he calls Silicon Valley a bunch of hypocrites. Here is part of his statement.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

AJIT PAI, FCC CHAIRMAN: Companies likes Facebook, and Amazon, and Netflix, and Google, became global giants precisely because the government wasn't involved. That's part of reason why I think so much of this hysteria is simply misplaced. As we will see going forward, getting this regulatory system, right, means better, faster cheaper internet access for all Americans across the country.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: So that is the FCC Chair. So actually he's kind of like --

WEBSTER: Ajit Pai -- so basically he says, this will enable, get government out of the way.

BOLTON: Yeah.

WEBSTER: It will enable the internet providers to get more money, if I want to pay for faster internet. I can, it's not like, the internet is going away.

BOLTON: So that's exactly the point.

WEBSTER: I can pay more if I want to.

BOLTON: So he has two offshoots. That first statement is very true.

WEBSTER: Right.

BOLTON: Actually Portugal is a live experiment in that.

WEBSTER: OK.

BOLTON: So people there, they pay for tiered internet access much as we pay for tiered cable access.

WEBSTER: Right.

BOLTON: It's essentially the same system, just with a different product.

WEBSTER: Got it.

BOLTON: Ajit Pai's second point, he is libertarian. So he just by definition, by philosophy is for less regulation. And he says, Verizon, Comcast, AT&T, the service providers. He said they don't really have a financial incentive to invest or to build in underserved areas, be they rural or low income earner --

WEBSTER: Right, this would give them the money to do it?

BOLTON: Well, I think his argument is that if they can make money and other ways charging Netflix or Facebook, then they will take that money, and build out broadband and maybe areas that are not as well-served.

WEBSTER: So bottom line is, it is not the end of world as we know it. We are all going to die at some point but not as a result of the FCC -- OK, very good. Deirdre, thank you very much. Good stuff.

U.N. Ambassador Nikki Haley presenting missile fragments that she says are indisputable evidence that Iran is violating U.N. resolutions and called out the regime as a threat to peace and security to the entire world. Dr. Walid Phares is here next to talk about that. Don't go away.

WEBSTER: More breaking news for on that tax reform bill. Mississippi Senator Thad Cochran's office announcing the senator will be in Washington next week to vote on the Republican tax reform bill. The senator had been in hospital for treatment for a non-melanoma lesion on his face. No word whether the Arizona Senator John McCain who is also in the hospital that is will be present for the vote but Thad Cochran will be there. That's what we've been told.

All right, in other news, Prime Minister Theresa May announcing the U.K. will lead the E.U. of March 2019. This as E.U. leaders agree to move on to the second stage of Brexit talks, which will focus on trade and future relations.

And CSX corps shares dropping after CEO takes unexpected medical leave, shrinking out nearly $6 billion a market value on that news. The leave comes as customers and regulators have questioned the company's turn around plan.

And Bitcoin hits another all-time high, almost hitting $18,000. Bitcoin has risen nearly 80 percent in just December alone. This has made billionaires out of the Winklevoss twins famous claiming they invented Facebook. Maria sat down with them and also about the concerns of a Bitcoin bubble.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CAMERON WINKLEVOSS, AMERICAN ROWER AND ENTREPRENEUR: But the bubble framework is really not correct to put against Bitcoin. When you think of a company, right, and their stock price, if they produce x-amount of units one year and the same amount of units the next year and the stock price goes up, and the economic doubles and economic productivity hasn't changed, the capital haven't changed with the company, we say that company is overvalued. But Bitcoin is not a company. It's a network.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WEBSTER: By the way you can watch the entire interview with the twins tonight on "Wall Street Week" right here on Fox Business at 8:00 p.m. Eastern Time. Don't miss that.

U.S. envoy Nikki Haley says the Trump administration now has proof that Iran is expanding its nuclear program and meddling in the Yemeni Civil War. And that came in the form of a charred piece of recovered ballistic missile. Take a look at that press conference in Washington yesterday.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

NIKKI HALEY, U.S. AMBASSADOR TO THE U.N.: When you look at this missile, this is terrifying, this is absolutely terrifying. And this is why it has to stop. We have said multiple times, that this is not just about the nuclear program. This is about everything else they're doing because Iran believes that they have been given a pass.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WEBSTER: So, did Iran really violate the nuclear deal? Here to discuss, Fox NewsForeign Affairs analyst Dr. Walid Phares. Walid, thank you so much for joining us.

So I notice that you said from Nikki Haley's conversations yesterday was one of the most advanced policy declarations on Iran by U.S. officials to date. Explain.

DR. WALID PHARES, FOX NEWSFOREIGN AFFAIRS ANALYST: It was really because Ambassador Haley after the speech of President in Riyadh a few months ago has pushed the explanation of what the U.S. position is very clearly.

Number one, Iran is now plotted to have been using those missiles through the militias via Yemen. And, you look at the video that the public has seen, and you see the actual missiles. So that is a very important point.

Number two, there is an interpretation, an American interpretation that those missiles are now deployed outside of Iran, which means that one of the actions that the U.S. is seeking from the international community and from the allies is to stop the shipping of those missiles and other equipment outside Iran which will tell me more about what's behind the horizons.

WEBSTER: It seems like the U.S. is a little bit alone on this. I will get into Saudi Arabia in a minute but you know, the Europeans, they continue to take this softly, softly approach, and believe that the U.S. is off kilter here because at least we have the Iranians locked date in some sort of a nuclear deal. But my thought on that, it is not a good deal in the first place and they are clearly violating it.

PHARES: Absolutely. I mean, it is tot a good deal. We all know that, most of us who criticized the deal, the administration and many members of the U.S. Congress. But what the Ambassador Haley has done, it's claim that OK, we have the criticism of the Iran dial. That's not what I'm talking about right now.

I'm talking about the missiles. And the minute she did that we'll going to have with us, maybe for the Arab and Muslim countries in the coalition. We're going to have with us France. Imagine that the President of France was also addressing missiles issue and maybe the U.K. and with them a number of eastern European and the central European countries concerned about those missiles.

Guess what? Some countries in Latin American, Africa, East Asia, all of these countries can come with us on the objection to the missiles regardless of the issue of the Iran nuclear deal.

WEBSTER: What is your interpretation, what is been going on in Saudi Arabia, in particularly the Crown Prince, the Saudi Crown Prince, Mohammad bin Salman, who's very anti-Iran and very strong on this, and by all accounts has been communicating with Israel. I mean, could we have a Saudi-Israel alliance to take on Iran? I mean, they are very, very aggressive in this field?

PHARES: I have been monitoring -- many observers have been analyzing the changes that have been taking place in Saudi Arabia. Even use a term which may not apply but could, enlighten us, Perestroika and Glasnost. It's when the Soviet Union started to changed course, unfortunately for them they collapsed.

What is happening here is that MBS, Mohammad bin Salman is trying to move Saudi Arabia in different direction. That is not easy. It's not done overnight.

So number one they canceled the power of religious belief, (ph) which was the must difficult thing to change and after that, giving rights to women. More important geopolitically, indeed, you're right he is mobilizing Saudi power and his allies in the peninsula and Arab allies against the expansion of Iranian military force in the region.

WEBSTER: Very quickly, I have 10 seconds, Walid, but we're seeing Iran's influence spread out, aren't we? We're seeing it take over some of the vacuum in Syria and Iraq?

PHARES: Yes.

WEBSTER: How concerned are you, how much dominance or at least the growth, if you like, of Iran outside of its own borders?

PHARES: Very quickly I have been very concerned for the last maybe nine years. Now that I see that there is an Arab coalition forming now, now that I see that we have a bridge with that coalition, I think we are now in the beginning of the phase to push back against Iran. This is just starting right now.

WEBSTER: Very good. We have to leave it right there. But it's great stuff. Dr. Walid Phares. Thank you so much, I appreciate it.

PHARES: Thank you.

WEBSTER: Thank you.

Americans spent much more than the economists predicted so far this holiday season. Confidence is high apparently. Good news for the economy and, of course, the retailers, our very own Jeff Flock in the Chicago among the crowds. There he is, very festive scene. We'll be going to Jeff, next.

WEBSTER: Guess what? Consumers going on a shopping spree last month with retail sales jumping nearly one percent in November, on line even better. The big win is of course as we know, the online retailers as well as electronics, I can't get enough of those and furniture. Not so much.

Now, is this a sign of more good things to come for consumer in 2018? Who better to ask Jeff Flock, who is live among the throngs of shoppers in Chicago. Jeff?

JEFF FLOCK, FBN CHICAGO-BASED REPORTER: State Street, out in front of what used to be called Marshall Fields. And I'll tell you, totally, Ashley, I came here on Christmas seasons past, I almost wrecked a picture of Santa Claus thus far.

We have come here before, and State Street has not been crowded. Today, I'll tell you, maybe you can see the Christmas spirit definitely in full swing. And today, not just for retailers that -- actual stores, brick-and- mortar, but today this is what they call a free shipping Friday.

More than 900 retailers around the country offering free shipping on all orders today. You don't even have to have a minimum order, which you have to for a lot of folks. These retailers, everybody from Macy's, to Target, J.C. Penney, Saks, the whole bunch 900 plus. If you go to free shipping day.com we get a full list.

Now back out here on State Street, maybe you see the beautiful windows used to be Marshall Fields. It is now Macy's. And Macy's has done really well. Take a look at the stocks over the course of the past months of multiple retailers. Macy's actually top of the list, up 25 in the last month. Nordstrom up 16 percent. Walmart up nine percent.

Why? Well, maybe it's because, so long people are getting paychecks. It used to be 2009, November 2009, unemployment was about 10 percent.

Now we're about 4.1 percent. And I'll tell you, believe me, Ashley, heard of the little drummer boys you got a whole bunch of them out here today, very talented folks, entertaining the shoppers along State Street as they look at the Marshall Fields windows (INAUDIBLE) decades along State Street.

What's known as today, the most wonderful time of the year for retailers? Ashley.

WEBSTER: Fantastic job, Jeff Flock. Great drumming. I have a headache. But it was wonderful, very, very good indeed. They were talented.

WEBSTER: All right, Star Wars: The Last Jedi opening today to rave reviews and what is expected to be Blockbuster tickets sales, the force is strong with this one. We could see a record opening weekend. We've got a preview for you, next.

WEBSTER: For the finalized tax bill is supposed to be released around 5:30 made public. It wasn't good enough for our own Blake Burman. He managed to get his hand on it right now. Blake, what are you seeing in that bill?

BURMAN: And as of it, it's coming to from several sources here in Washington and the first thing that jumps out, which not going to put all the numbers up right now, we were just given them.

The first thing that jumps up is seven different brackets, that being 10, 12, 22, 24, 32, 35, 37. The original Senate bill is what won out here. Because what the individual side of this is the same as what first appeared in the individual Senate bill. The tweaks that are made to it are on side, where it's those who are married or filing jointly.

The top end rate has gotten a lot of talk, on individual side. It will be $500,000 at 37 percent. On the married filing jointly side, it will be 600,000 and above. That number has dropped substantially from the initial Senate plan. It was initially at a million dollars. So that got slashed some 40 percent, where the tinkering is, again it's on the married filing jointly side, when you start to play with brackets in between, there some numbers raid, some numbers lowered but the headline here is what we are getting from expect posted publicly here at 5:30. The seven brackets, and it appears, not appears, what happened in the Senate bill and initially, won out here.

WEBSTER: Yes, certainly appears that way. Great stuff, Blake Burman, thank you very much.

Of course, they'll be pouring tomorrow that bill as he gets the time to do that. But those are the headline numbers that you saw just the -- Blake, thank you very much.

The "Star Wars" franchise is certainly a force to be reckoned with, as we know that, the latest chapter in the legendary series, The Last Jedi, now in theaters and on track for me as the largest movie opening ever.

Joining me now to discuss all the light saber swinging action, comScore Incorporated Senior Media Analyst Paul Dergarabedian. Paul, thank you for joining me, have you seen the movie? I assume you have. Is it a home run?

PAUL DERGARABEDIAN, COMSCORE'S SENIOR MEDIA ANALYST: I sure have.

WEBSTER: It is a home run?

DERGARABEDIAN: It's a total home run. I saw the movie, of course, this is the follow-up to 2015's, "The Force Awakens" which opened in North America to the biggest debut ever, $248 million.

Now, that long two years ago, had a 57 million preview night on Thursday. This film had the second biggest Thursday preview with 45 million. So the Last Jedi is off to rollicking start, and could join the 200 million club for opening weekend in North America. Not only has three films on the list right now, this could be the 4th. So a huge deal for the movie industry this weekend.

WEBSTER: Am I right, Paul that it's two and a half hour long or did I misread that? And it has going to be good to occupy for two and a half hours?

DERGARABEDIAN: Yes, I already say a great movie can't be long enough and if it's a terrible move, anything over now would be, you know, you'd suffer thought that. But I think what we're seeing in the comScore data, we do exit polling. So we have a service called post-track. And this is movie is showing five out of five stars. You can't get higher than that in our survey. 82 percent definite recommend. So that means audiences are loving it. The critics are loving it. And that's how you get to a billion dollars in worldwide Box Office and beyond.

And we're already showing that the film has earned $106 million in two days, globally. And now it's poised for a massive weekend worldwide. And it really a global business --

WEBSTER: Indeed, it is.

DERGARABEDIAN: And the "Star Wars" franchise is a global phenomenon, and this sets us on really strong pace for the rest of the bock office share, which we have about two weeks left.

You know, "Star Wars" fanatics are very fiercely protective of the property. You know that very quickly, Paul.

DERGARABEDIAN: Right.

WEBSTER: It seems like Disney is doing a good job with continuing this franchise.

DERGARABEDIAN: Yeah, they are. I mean, you know, it's a huge amount of responsibility to take this on with the first movie opening in 1977. The franchise just in theaters worldwide up to this point about $7.5 billion, you add the merchandising on to that. And then, of course, we have next Memorial Day, the Han Solo movie. And two years from now will be episode nine, the next installment in this new trilogy, and the final installment in this new trilogy. So this is the gift that keeps on giving to Disney. This is a long term play. We're talking about decades long, you know, everyone's kids and their grand kids will be seeing "Star Wars" movies for the next many decades.

WEBSTER: Wow. I think you're all right there. Paul Dergarabedian. Paul, thank you very much. I will two and a half hours --

DERGARABEDIAN: Thank you, Ashley.

WEBSTER: I'll take your advice. I will go and watch it. Thank you so much.

As we get ready to hand over to Liz Claman. The Dow up 157 points. What a great way to finish the week. The Dow at 24,666, ominously, but there you go, good day for the market. Our time is up. Liz Claman, over to you.

urn:contentItem:5W8N-YWB1-JDJ6-K021-00000-00GOP lawmakers divided on House antitrust tech probe2019-06-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:56:44ZLexisNexisPOLITICOPICKSGOP lawmakers divided on House antitrust tech probeclima@politico.com (Cristiano Lima)

The House Judiciary Committee launched a probe Monday to look at whether Silicon Valley's tech titans have engaged in anti-competitive conduct.

Republicans are split over a new Democrat-led antitrust investigation of the tech industry, highlighting tensions between the GOP's growing criticism of companies like Google and Facebook and the party's traditional aversion to regulating business.

The House Judiciary Committee launched the probe Monday to look at whether Silicon Valley's tech titans have engaged in anti-competitive conduct - and some Republican lawmakers were quick to cheer their Democratic colleagues on.

"I'm all for it," Senate Judiciary Chairman Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.) said of the House probe, while fellow Senate Judiciary member John Neely Kennedy (R-La.) told reporters that it's about time for Congress to examine how the online industry's growing power affects consumers.

"Look I'm very proud of the large social media companies," Kennedy told reporters. "They're all American companies. They've been extraordinarily successful. That's why they're so big. But they're not companies anymore - they're countries."

Other congressional Republicans tempered their enthusiasm, however. And others responded with distinct caution to the idea of Congress taking on an antitrust role that's normally in the hands of the Justice Department and the Federal Trade Commission - both of which have lately taken an interest in tech giants such as Google and Amazon.

"Antitrust is a highly technical inquiry, not something that lends itself to easy generalizations or blanket condemnations," said a statement from Utah Sen. Mike Lee, who chairs the Senate Judiciary antitrust panel that would be in a prime position to oversee a probe. "This is why such investigations are best left to the antitrust agencies rather than Congress."

Sen. Josh Hawley (R-Mo.), a leading critic of the tech industry, agreed that federal regulators would be "more effective" than Congress in policing the issue. He suggested that lawmakers should instead focus on issues like protecting consumers' data privacy.

The reactions underscore the dueling impulses of Republicans when it comes to tech in the Trump era. Many have railed against internet giants like Google, Facebook and Twitter, particularly over what they see as an anti-conservative bias in the way the companies manage content. Some have dangled the prospect of taking away the industry's longtime liability protections. But most Republicans also hew to the party's instinctive distaste for anything that smacks of regulation - let alone trust-busting.

The GOP's more hawkish tech critics include Graham, who has complained about the unregulated "wild wild West" of social media companies and said he's "certainly willing to look into their business model" as well. Another is Texas Sen. Ted Cruz, who has accused digital platforms of suppressing conservative speech.

"I was glad to see the House launch that investigation and I'd love to see Senate Judiciary Committee do the same," Cruz said.

House Democrats have yet to lay out the full scope of the probe. But Rep. David Cicilline (D-R.I.), chairman of the House Judiciary antitrust subcommittee that is spearheading the congressional investigation, specifically named Google, Facebook and Amazon as a "significant part" of it during his announcement Monday. He said he's prepared to issue subpoenas and compel witnesses to testify if needed.

House Judiciary's top Republican, Doug Collins of Georgia, and Jim Sensenbrenner of Wisconsin, the top Republican on its antitrust panel, initially praised the Democrats' probe, with Collins calling the effort a "bipartisan" opportunity to explore whether the tech industry remains competitive and "if necessary, to take action."

But a GOP committee aide later sought to draw some boundaries around that support, suggesting the two Republican lawmakers are leery of some of the more aggressive tactics Cicilline mentioned.

Collins and Sensenbrenner have agreed to "less formal oversight activity to look into big tech," said the aide, who spoke anonymously because they were not authorized to speak on the record. The aide added that "there has not been bipartisan agreement to scrutinize, subpoena, compel testimony from or start a critical investigation" into specific companies.

That reluctance contrasts with some of the fiery rhetoric Republicans have brandished as they take aim at perceived bias on the part of Google, Facebook and Twitter, which deny any political favoritism in the way they manage their platforms.

Several GOP lawmakers, including Cruz and Hawley, have even floated the idea of revisiting a 1996 law that gives websites immunity from lawsuits over content their users have posted. It's a critical provision for the internet industry, shielding companies from expensive litigation if something libelous pops up in a search result, YouTube video or Facebook post, for example.

The tech antitrust issue isn't likely to dissipate for Republicans anytime soon, with the topic taking center stage in the Democratic presidential field. Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.) has called for a breakup of Facebook, Google, Amazon and Apple, and Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) is backing calls to split up Facebook.

Meanwhile, the Justice Department has opened the door to its own possible antitrust investigation of Google, although it has yet to say whether it will launch such a probe. People familiar with DOJ's activities confirmed to POLITICO and other news organizations last week that the department has taken jurisdiction over any potential Google probe as part of a recent agreement with the Federal Trade Commission.

The Justice Department has also claimed jurisdiction over any antitrust claims involving Apple, while the FTC would handle any investigations of Facebook and Amazon, according to news reports and sources familiar with the cases. The two agencies periodically get together to divide up companies in industry groups and determine which agency will handle an investigation, should there be infractions that would warrant investigation, an FTC official has told POLITICO.

Whether any of these procedural moves will blossom into full-blown investigations, or result in fines or other penalties, is still unclear. But all four companies have faced complaints in both the U.S. and Europe from rivals who accuse them of abusing their dominant roles.

Article originally published on POLITICO Magazine

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5TY4-G081-JC8J-41X5-00000-00GOP Lawmakers Grill Google CEO on Perceived Bias2018-12-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:56:44ZLexisNexisNEWSTAGGOP Lawmakers Grill Google CEO on Perceived BiasAssociated Press

House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy kicked off a congressional grilling of Google CEO Sundar Pichai by noting a "widening gap of distrust" between tech companies and the American people.

McCarthy, a California Republican, asked whether tech companies are "serving as instruments of freedom or instruments of control" in the U.S. and beyond.

Pichai is facing the Republican-majority House Judiciary Committee before Democrats take control of the House in January. Lawmakers are asking him about alleged bias in the company's search results, as well as its reported plans to launch a censored search engine in China.

Pichai's appearance comes after he angered members of a Senate panel in September by declining their invitation to testify about foreign governments' manipulation of online services to sway U.S. elections. Pichai's no-show at that hearing was marked by an empty chair for Google alongside the Facebook and Twitter executives who did appear.

Pichai went to Washington later in September to mend fences, meeting with some two dozen Republicans and indicating he also planned to meet with Democrats. He took part last week in a White House meeting with other tech industry executives that focused mainly on getting government and businesses working more closely on accelerating emerging technologies such as artificial intelligence.

In October, Google announced it was shutting down its long-shunned Plus social network following its disclosure of a flaw discovered in March that could have exposed some personal information of as many as 500,000 people. The company deliberately avoided disclosing the privacy lapse at the time, in part to avoid drawing regulators' scrutiny and damaging its reputation, according to a Wall Street Journal report citing anonymous individuals and documents.

Lawmakers want Google to explain its failure to reveal the breach.

On Monday, the company said it was accelerating its plans to shutter Plus after discovering a privacy flaw that inadvertently exposed the names, email addresses, ages and other personal information of 52.5 million users last month. The service will now go dark in April instead of August, as previously announced.

"We work hard to ensure the integrity of our products, and we've put a number of checks and balances in place to ensure they continue to live up to our standards," Pichai said in his opening statement prepared for Tuesday's hearing.

Lawmakers are also concerned by recent reports that Google is poised to re-enter China with a search engine generating censored results to comply with the demands of that country's Communist government.

President Donald Trump has accused Google of rigging the results of its dominant search engine to suppress conservative viewpoints and highlight coverage from media that he says distribute "fake news." That's another area of potential questions to Pichai by committee members.

The company has denied any political bias, and there's no evidence of an anti-conservative tilt. Pichai said in his written testimony that "I lead this company without political bias and work to ensure that our products continue to operate that way. To do otherwise would go against our core principles and our business interests."

Google has good reason to communicate with lawmakers and policymakers, and to seek to weigh in on thorny issues. Trump and some lawmakers have raised the possibility of asking regulators to investigate whether Google - which handles nearly two of every three online searches in the U.S. - has abused its clout as a major gateway to the internet to stifle competition.

And momentum is building in Congress for legislation to put stricter limits and privacy protections around the big tech companies' collection of data. With the Democrats having captured control of the House in the midterm elections, and poised to take over as the majority running the Judiciary Committee next month, tougher legislation could be in the offing.

Pichai, a former engineer, took the helm of Google in 2015 in a major restructuring that made Google a division of conglomerate Alphabet Inc. - whose businesses include Waymo, a self-driving technology development company. Bolstering the dominance of its search engine, Google's Android operating system runs most of the world's smartphones, and its other services - including Gmail, YouTube, online ads and the Chrome web browser - are widely used.

urn:contentItem:60DR-8391-F07F-80XP-00000-00GOP Leader Demands Twitter CEO Testify In Antitrust Probe2020-07-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:56:44ZLexisNexisNEWSGOP Leader Demands Twitter CEO Testify In Antitrust Probe

U.S. House Republicans want to add Twitter ’s CEO to the roster of Big Tech execs scheduled to testify later this month before a congressional antitrust panel. GOP Rep. Jim Jordan , ranking member of the House Committee on the Judiciary, said in a letter ,... U.S. House Republicans...

U.S. House Republicans want to add Twitter ’s CEO to the roster of Big Tech execs scheduled to testify later this month before a congressional antitrust panel. GOP Rep. Jim Jordan , ranking member of the House Committee on the Judiciary, said in a letter ,...

U.S. House Republicans want to add Twitter ’s CEO to the roster of Big Tech execs scheduled to testify later this month before a congressional antitrust panel. GOP Rep. Jim Jordan , ranking member of the House Committee on the Judiciary, said in a letter , “there is bipartisan interest to hear from Twitter about its power in the marketplace, its role in moderating content on its platform, and the causes for its recent highly publicized security breaches.” The letter was addressed to Democratic U.S. Rep. Jerrold L. Nadler , who is chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, Jordan insisted that Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey should appear on July 27. That’s in addition to the existing antitrust lineup : Amazon ’s Jeff Bezos, Facebook ’s Mark Zuckerberg, Google ’s Sundar Pichai and Apple ’s Tim Cook. All are set to appear before the Judiciary Committee’s antitrust panel. All four companies are also being looked into by the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ). The House hearing is part of an investigation into the tech giants. The outcome of that investigation is expected to produce legislation that would reform and regulate the online world. Jordan’s letter to Nadler said, “I write to notify you that we are calling Jack Dorsey, the CEO of Twitter, to testify at this hearing and we expect that you will transmit an invitation to him promptly.” As justification, he said, that as Congress “considers large technology companies and the competitive landscape, a thorough examination cannot exclude Twitter, a market leader in social media. The upcoming hearing represents a significant and unique opportunity to explore these issues with respect to Twitter.” The concern has long been that each of the four Big Tech firms have used their position to squeeze out competition and dominate the market. U.S. Rep. David Cicilline of Rhode Island, chairman of the House antitrust panel, has said there is not enough competition in the U.S. tech scene and he wants to change that. This would be the first time all four Big Tech CEOs have testified together before Congress, although all of them except Bezos have done so separately in the past. —————————— New PYMNTS Study: Subscription Commerce Conversion Index – July 2020 Staying home 24/7 has consumers turning to subscription services for both entertainment and their day-to-day needs. While that’s a great opportunity for providers, it also presents a challenge — 27.4 million consumers are looking to cancel their subscriptions because of friction and cost concerns. In the latest Subscription Commerce Conversion Index , PYMNTS reveals the five key features that can help companies keep subscribers loyal despite today’s challenging economic times. Recommended for you

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5X94-Y0W1-JCMN-Y3FV-00000-00GOP Rep. Warns of Danger of Big Government Regulating Tech2019-10-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:56:44ZLexisNexisGOP Rep. Warns of Danger of Big Government Regulating TechCorinne Weaver

Oct 17, 2019( Newsbusters.org: http://newsbusters.org/ Delivered by Newstex) Big tech has presented many problems for the legislators in Washington to tackle. One of those is regulation.Many politicians on both sides of the aisle have discussed government regulation of Big Tech. Government regulation and amending Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act are seen as a solution to the scandals plaguing tech companies.

But not all politicians are convinced of these solutions' effectiveness. Rep. Cathy McMorris Rodgers (R-WA) warned[1] of the 'unintended consequences' amending or repealing Section 230 could have for free speech.On Twitter, Rodgers called[2] for 'a serious ...oughtful discussion on achieving the balance of #Section230.' She then stated[3], 'I'm not for gutting it.' Rodgers described Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act, which provided legal protection for tech companies from the consequences of users' posts, as 'essential for consumers and innovators in the Internet ecosystem.'A House hearing of subcommittees, which included testimonies from Google and Reddit executives, was held on Oct. 16. Google's Global Head of Intellectual Property Policy Katherine Oyama and Reddit CEO Steve Huffman strongly defended[4] Section 230 as necessary for their respective platforms.Conservatives and liberals alike have discussed making changes to Section 230. Senator Josh Hawley (R-MO) introduced a bill[5] in June called the Ending Support for Internet Censorship Act[6], which would revoke the immunity enjoyed by Big Tech companies. The White House[7] allegedly had a proposal as well, called 'Protecting Americans from Online Censorship,' which would revoke the protection of Section 230 for a platform if there was an abuse of it.Rodgers stated[8], 'These proposals are not consistent with the First Amendment.' She argued that the FCC, the FTC or any other government agency should not have control over the moderation of speech on the internet. Rather, 'we should continue to provide oversight of Big Tech ...eir use of #Section230, and also encourage constructive discussions on the responsible use of content moderation,' she wrote[9].A Gallup[10] poll from August found that 48 percent of Americans wanted Big Tech to be regulated further, while 40 percent did not. 56 percent of Democrats polled wanted more, tighter government control over tech platforms, compared to 48 percent of Republicans.Tech executives have also surprisingly called for an increase of government regulation. Microsoft President Brad Smith[11] told NPR that regulation would protect 'something that is far more important than technology: democracy.'However, in Europe, government regulation of companies like Facebook and Google is backfiring as the values of the companies clash with the mandates of the European Union. Facebook[12] faced a ruling from an Austrian court to take down content that violated Austrian law across the globe. Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5X94-JC51-DXKX-0561-00000-00GOP Rep. Warns of Danger of Big Government Regulating Tech2019-10-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:56:44ZLexisNexisGOP Rep. Warns of Danger of Big Government Regulating Tech

Oct 17, 2019( Newsbusters.org: http://newsbusters.org/Delivered by Newstex) Big tech has presented many problems for the legislators in Washington to tackle. One of those is regulation.Many politicians on both sides of the aisle have discussed government regulation of Big Tech. Government regulation and amending Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act are seen as a solution to the scandals plaguing tech companies.

But not all politicians are convinced of these solutions' effectiveness. Rep. Cathy McMorris Rodgers (R-WA) warned[1] of the 'unintended consequences' amending or repealing Section 230 could have for free speech.On Twitter, Rodgers called[2] for 'a serious thoughtful discussion on achieving the balance of #Section230.' She then stated[3], 'I'm not for gutting it.' Rodgers described Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act, which provided legal protection for tech companies from the consequences of users' posts, as 'essential for consumers and innovators in the Internet ecosystem.'A House hearing of subcommittees, which included testimonies from Google and Reddit executives, was held on Oct. 16. Google's Global Head of Intellectual Property Policy Katherine Oyama and Reddit CEO Steve Huffman strongly defended[4] Section 230 as necessary for their respective platforms.Conservatives and liberals alike have discussed making changes to Section 230. Senator Josh Hawley (R-MO) introduced a bill[5] in June called the Ending Support for Internet Censorship Act[6], which would revoke the immunity enjoyed by Big Tech companies. The White House[7] allegedly had a proposal as well, called 'Protecting Americans from Online Censorship,' which would revoke the protection of Section 230 for a platform if there was an abuse of it.Rodgers stated[8], 'These proposals are not consistent with the First Amendment.' She argued that the FCC, the FTC or any other government agency should not have control over the moderation of speech on the internet. Rather, 'we should continue to provide oversight of Big Tech their use of #Section230, and also encourage constructive discussions on the responsible use of content moderation,' she wrote[9].A Gallup[10] poll from August found that 48 percent of Americans wanted Big Tech to be regulated further, while 40 percent did not. 56 percent of Democrats polled wanted more, tighter government control over tech platforms, compared to 48 percent of Republicans.Tech executives have also surprisingly called for an increase of government regulation. Microsoft President Brad Smith[11] told NPR that regulation would protect 'something that is far more important than technology: democracy.'However, in Europe, government regulation of companies like Facebook and Google is backfiring as the values of the companies clash with the mandates of the European Union. Facebook[12] faced a ruling from an Austrian court to take down content that violated Austrian law across the globe. Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5RCG-NXT1-JDH3-G3PV-00000-00GoPro cuts 20 per cent of its jobs;Bailing out on its drone unit2018-01-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:56:44ZLexisNexisBUSINESSPg. C3GoPro cuts 20 per cent of its jobsBailing out on its drone unitJing CaoBloomberg

GoPro said it's cutting more than 20 per cent of its global workforce and putting an end to its drone business after a disappointing fourth quarter.

The company said it now expects sales of about $340 million, well short of its own previous projection of as much as $480 million and the average analyst estimate of $472 million. Revenue took an $80 million hit due to discounting for its Karma drones, as well as its Hero line of cameras, over the holiday season, the company said.

GoPro has faced intensifying competition in the action camera market, as big tech companies from Samsung Electronics to Google have started selling similar products. Some analysts have said that the Hero cameras have become a commodity, and that GoPro's main selling point now is its brand.

In November, Raymond James analyst Tavis McCourt wrote that there hasn't been a noticeable bump from GoPro's newest camera in the Hero line, and it's turning up less in searches and app downloads.

GoPro's Karma drone was supposed to help turn around the business when it was launched in September 2016. Instead, it's been plagued by problems from production delays to a recall of 2,500 units due to a battery issue.

The Karma also had to go up against China's SZ DJI Technology Co., the biggest drone-maker in the world. GoPro said low margins and a hostile regulatory market in Europe and the U.S. makes the drone market "untenable." It will exit the market after selling its remaining inventory and continue to service existing drones.

Chief executive officer Nicholas Woodman will reduce his 2018 cash compensation to $1. Chief operating officer Charles Prober is also leaving the company next month.

GoPro is cutting more than 250 jobs, reducing its workforce to fewer than 1,000 people. The job cuts and business restructuring will result in an estimated charge of $23 million to $33 million, most of which will be recognized in the first quarter, the company said.

"GoPro is committed to turning our business around in 2018," Woodman said in the statement. "We expect that going forward, our road map coupled with a lower operating expense model will enable GoPro to return to profitability and growth in the second half of 2018."

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5RC9-SXB1-JBTY-W0TX-00000-00GoPro cuts chunk of workforce, drone program after dismal results;Revenue takes large hit due to discount offerings over the holiday season2018-01-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:56:44ZLexisNexisBUSINESSPg. GT10GoPro cuts chunk of workforce, drone program after dismal resultsRevenue takes large hit due to discount offerings over the holiday seasonJing Cao BloombergNew York

GoPro Inc. said it's cutting more than 20 per cent of its global workforce and putting an end to its drone business after a disappointing fourth quarter.

The company said it now expects sales of about $340 million (U.S.), well short of its own previous projection of as much as $480 million and the average analyst estimate of $472 million.

Revenue took an $80-million hit due to discounting its Karma drones, as well as its Hero line of cameras, over the holiday season, the company said.

In December, GoPro started lowering prices for its older Hero5 Black cameras due to soft demand, despite the company spending significantly on marketing the product, chief executive officer Nicholas Woodman said in a statement. On Sunday, GoPro also cut the price of its newest Hero camera by $100 to $399.

"There's only so much market for a $500 stand-alone camera, so that they cut the Hero6 Black camera price is not a surprise," said Longbow Research analyst Joe Wittine i. "That they cut it three months after the launch though does illustrate that the action-camera market is a difficult market right now." He downgraded GoPro to a neutral rating Monday.

The stock fell as much as 33 per cent to $5.04, its biggest ever drop and its lowest price since going public in 2014.

Stiff competition

GoPro has faced intensifying competition in the action-camera market, as big tech companies from Samsung Electronics Co. Ltd. to Alphabet Inc.'s Google have started selling similar products. Some analysts have said that the Hero cameras have become a commodity, and that GoPro's main selling point now is its brand. In November, Raymond James analyst Tavis McCourt wrote that there hasn't been a noticeable bump from GoPro's newest camera in the Hero line, and it's turning up less in searches and app downloads.

GoPro's Karma drone was supposed to help turn around the business when it was launched in September 2016.

Instead, it's been plagued by problems from production delays to a recall of 2,500 units due to a battery issue.

The Karma also faces stiff competition from China's SZ DJI Technology Co., the biggest drone-maker in the world. GoPro said low margins and a hostile regulatory market in Europe and the U.S. makes the drone market "untenable." It will exit the market after selling its remaining inventory and continue to service existing drones.

Woodman, who was the highest paid CEO in the U.S. in 2014, will reduce his 2018 cash compensation to $1. Chief operating officer Charles Prober is leaving the company next month.

GoPro is cutting more than 250 jobs, reducing its workforce to fewer than 1,000 people. The job cuts and business restructuring will result in an estimated charge of $23 to $33 million, most of which will be recognized in the first quarter, the company said.

"GoPro is committed to turning our business around in 2018," Woodman said in the statement.

"We expect that going forward, our road map coupled with a lower operating expense model will enable GoPro to return to profitability and growth in the second half of 2018."

urn:contentItem:5RCJ-6PV1-JCK9-7488-00000-00GoPro slashes jobs, will drop out of drone field2018-01-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:56:44ZLexisNexisA,APg. 6GoPro slashes jobs, will drop out of drone fieldRex Crumrcrum@bayareanewsgroup.com

Sport-camera maker GoPro confirmed Monday that it will slash at least 20 percent of its workforce and drop its Karma drone business as it restructures operations.

The San Mateo company has faced weakening sales and the lack of a new hit product. It also released preliminary earnings Monday for the final quarter of 2017 that fell short of analysts' expectations.

Before U.S. stock markets opened, GoPro said the job cuts would leave the company with fewer than 1,000 workers, down from its current level of 1,254 employees. CEO Nick Woodman also said he would cut his cash compensation for 2018 to $1.

All the bad news from GoPro slammed the company's shares Monday, as GoPro's stock price fell 21 percent to $5.95. GoPro shares are down by 75 percent from their $24-a-share price when the company went public in June 2014.

GoPro has faced intensifying competition in the action camera market as big tech companies such as Samsung Electronics Co. Ltd. and Alphabet Inc.'s Google have started selling similar products. Some analysts have said that GoPro's Hero cameras have become a commodity and that the company's main selling point now is its brand.

In November, Raymond James analyst Tavis McCourt wrote that there hasn't been a noticeable bump from GoPro's newest camera in the Hero line and that it's turning up less in searches and app downloads.

The company is pulling the plug on its Karma drone business after more than a year of false starts, product stumbles and disappointing sales.

GoPro said that even though the $800 Karma has reached the No. 2 position in the U.S. for drones in its "price band," the company decided the drone market was "untenable" because of "a hostile regulatory environment in Europe and the United States (that) will likely reduce the total addressable market in the years ahead."

GoPro initially put the Karma on sale in October 2016 but pulled it from the market after just 16 days. That followed reports of technical issues that caused the drones to drop from the sky as they were flying. GoPro put the Karma back on the market in February 2017.

Michael Pachter of Wedbush Securities said GoPro became a victim of both hubris and desperation as it tried to make a go of it in the drone sector.

"Drones are a competitive space," Pachter said. "Karma was priced significantly higher than the competition, and the GoPro brand wasn't enough for consumers to justify the higher price. I think they made a strategic error in pursuing entry into such a competitive space, and it proves how hard consumer electronics innovation has become."

GoPro also released preliminary fourth-quarter results, which didn't do anything to inspire investors' confidence. GoPro said it expects sales for the quarter that ended Dec. 31 to be $340 million, a 37 percent decline from the same period a year ago. Wall Street analysts had earlier forecast GoPro to report sales of $472 million for the quarter.

Bloomberg contributed to this report.

Wall Street analysts had earlier forecast GoPro to report sales of $472 million for the quarter.

Bloomberg contributed to this report.
